Activity: Log in to the OA system, check emails, and respond to any urgent requests. Review the week's goals and Naomi's design document thoroughly.
Begin defining core game mechanics: Movement. Outline the different movement types (walking, running, crouching, jumping), their speeds, and associated animations. Note initial values for testing.

Start documenting the movement mechanics definition. Create a detailed document outlining the different movement types, their input triggers, speeds, and animation states. Emphasize clarity and future maintainability.
Define core game mechanics: Combat. Outline basic combat actions (attack, block, dodge), their input methods, and initial damage values. Consider the relationship between movement and combat.

Continue documenting the combat mechanics definition. Add this to the existing documentation, outlining the combat actions, input triggers, damage calculations, and animation states. Cross-reference with the movement section where relevant.

Define core game mechanics: Interactions. Brainstorm potential interactive elements in the game world (doors, switches, items). Describe how the player will interact with these elements and the consequences of those interactions.

Document the interaction mechanics. Add to the existing document, detailing the types of interactive elements, interaction triggers, and possible outcomes. Include any dependencies on movement or combat.

Review all documented core game mechanics (Movement, Combat, Interactions) for completeness and clarity. Ensure consistency in terminology and formatting. Prepare for discussion with Lead Game Designer.
